intro: Bombacopsis dugandeana, commonly known as the Andean kapok tree, is a flowering plant native to the cloud forests of South America. It belongs to the Malvaceae family and is characterized by its large, showy flowers that bloom in clusters. The plant produces a heavy, fibrous seed pod that contains seeds with a fleshy, edible aril. Its bark and leaves have been used traditionally for their medicinal properties. The tree can grow up to 30 meters tall and is valued for its ecological role in supporting biodiversity.
